[//]: # (NOTE: links are tricky with OPENAPI in that they are not renderer agnostic. The form of the links used here is that used by redoc, and specific to having the settings.OPENAPI_STR env variable set to '/api/v1' which is probably not the case if running locally, so links will not work if not using redoc or /api/v1)

# Introduction

The Pio API provides a software layer to build integrations that allows communication between the Pio Platform (WES) and third party services (erp, shipping, etc.).

# Getting started

To start building an integration you need a `client_id` and `client_secret`. To obtain these credentials, please contact [Pio API Support (integrations@pio.com)](mailto:integrations@pio.com).

# Authorization

The `client_id` and `client_secret` for your integration is then used to obtain an access token for a Pio organization via a standard OAuth process.

Start by redirecting the user to the Pio authorization URL at `https://app.test.pio.com//raw/openapi_auth/authorize_form`. The following query arguments must be included in the request:
 - `client_id`: your integration's `client_id`
 - `redirect_uri`: used to redirect the user back to your integration after they accept the authorization request.
 - `state` (optional): If set, is included in the query arguments of the redirect back to your integraion. Use if it's needed to match the original request to the final callback.

Example:

    https://app.test.pio.com//raw/openapi_auth/authorize_form?client_id=aRfNZeYtjhuqEClMCkZrFPeItnHOwOdN&redirect_uri=http://localhost/authorize&state=abc

After the user approves the authorization request, they will be redirected back to the specified `redirect_uri`. The redirect will include the following query parameters:
 - `timestamp`: a Unix timestamp indicating the time the request was made.
 - `organization_id`: the ID of the Pio organization that was authorized.
 - `code`: the OAuth authorization code
 - `state` (optional): the `state` value provided with the original authorization request (if provided).
 - `hmac`:  a HMAC-SHA256 signature, signing the rest of the query string using your integration's `client_secret`.

 The `hmac` can be used to verify that the redirect actually came from Pio. To verify the signature, remove the `hmac=...&` part of the query string, generate a HMAC-SHA256 signature from the remaining parts and verify it matches the provided `hmac`.

Example python code:

    import hashlib
    import hmac
    import secrets

    # your integration's `client_secret`
    client_secret: str = <...>
    # get the query string from the request
    query_string: str = "hmac=...&timestamp=12313123123&organization_id=1&code=NhLPgnoEbpqotXDm"
    hmac_query_arg, data_to_sign = query_string.split("&", 1)
    provided_hmac = hmac_query_arg[5:]
    signature = hmac.new(
        client_secret.encode("utf-8"),
        msg=data_to_sign.encode("utf-8"),
        digestmod=hashlib.sha256
    ).hexdigest()
    # the following should result in `True` if the signatures match
    valid = secrets.compare_digest(provided_hmac, signature)

You can then use the `code` value to obtain an access token for the organization using the [Get Access Token](#tag/oauth/operations/get_access_token_api_v1_oauth_access_token_post) endpoint.

Include the access token in the `Authorization` header as a `Bearer` token for all subsequent requests.

Example:

    Authorization: Bearer <access token>

The access token does not expire, so no refresh is needed.

# Webhooks

[Webhooks](#tag/hooks) are used to receive notifications when there are updates relevent to your integration. Details about webhooks relevent to specific integrations is included in the relevent integration sections below.

## Response Requirements

Pio expects the hook to return a response with a `2XX` status code, e.g. `200` or `204`.

Pio also expects the response to happen within 5 seconds. If you take longer than 5 seconds to respond, Pio will send the request again following the rules of the retry mechanism listed below.

It is recommended that the response to the webhook request should simply indicate that the webhook was received, and the actual processing of webhook data should be done by a separate process outside of the request context.

## Retry Mechanism

If Pio receives a non-`2XX` status code in the response, or the request times out, it will retry for up to 24 hours before giving up.

Retried requests will have the same `X-Pio-Delivery-Id` header to provide idempotency.

## Verification

To verify the webhook requests are sent by Pio and not other sources (e.g. attackers), the requests are signed using a HMAC-SHA256 signature generated from your integration's `client_secret`.

The request headers will include the signature and other information that can be used to compute and verify the signature.

## Version 1 webhooks

The included headers are:

 - `X-Pio-Hmac-Sha256`: The HMAC-SHA256 signature.
 - `X-Pio-Delivery-Id` : The ID of the webhook, used for idempotency.
 - `X-Pio-Event-Type`: The type of event the webhook refers to. Event types are described in the relevant secetions below.
 - `X-Pio-Shop-Id`: The Pio ID for the shop the webhook is targetting.
 - `X-Pio-Ext-Shop-Id`: The integration provided ID for the shop the webhook is targetting.
 - `X-Pio-Timestamp`: A Unix timestamp indicating the time the request was made.

Example python code for verifying a Pio wehook:

    import hashlib
    import hmac
    import base64
    import secrets

    # your integration's `client_secret`
    client_secret: str = <...>
    # get the payload from the request
    payload: bytes = <...>
    payload_str = payload.decode('utf-8')
    data_to_sign = f"{x_pio_event_type}:{x_pio_delivery_id}:{x_pio_timestamp}:{x_pio_shop_id}:{x_pio_ext_shop_id}:{payload_str}"
    signature = hmac.new(
        client_secret.encode("utf-8"),
        msg=data_to_sign.encode("utf-8"),
        digestmod=hashlib.sha256
    ).digest()
    signature_base64 = base64.b64encode(signature).decode("utf-8")
    # the following should result in `True` if the signatures match
    valid = secrets.compare_digest(signature_base64, x_pio_hmac_sha256)


## Version 2 webhooks

In version 2 webhooks, the shop headers have been removed, and other relevant identification details are instead included in the payload.

Currently the version 2 webhook form is only used for the [shipment dispatch requests](#tag/hooks/operation/shipment_dispatch_request_example_openapi_v1__webhook_documentation_shipment_dispatch_post).

The included headers are:

 - `X-Pio-Hmac-Sha256`: The HMAC-SHA256 signature.
 - `X-Pio-Delivery-Id` : The ID of the webhook, used for idempotency.
 - `X-Pio-Event-Type`: The type of event the webhook refers to. Event types are described in the relevant secetions below.
 - `X-Pio-Timestamp`: A Unix timestamp indicating the time the request was made.

Example python code for verifying a Pio wehook:

    import hashlib
    import hmac
    import base64
    import secrets

    # your integration's `client_secret`
    client_secret: str = <...>
    # get the payload from the request
    payload: bytes = <...>
    payload_str = payload.decode('utf-8')
    data_to_sign = f"{x_pio_event_type}:{x_pio_delivery_id}:{x_pio_timestamp}:{payload_str}"
    signature = hmac.new(
        client_secret.encode("utf-8"),
        msg=data_to_sign.encode("utf-8"),
        digestmod=hashlib.sha256
    ).digest()
    signature_base64 = base64.b64encode(signature).decode("utf-8")
    # the following should result in `True` if the signatures match
    valid = secrets.compare_digest(signature_base64, x_pio_hmac_sha256)


# Shop Platform Integrations

Shop platform integrations are responsible for providing Pio with product and fulfillment order data.

For these integrations, the root entity is the `shop`. All shop platform operations require that you first create a `shop`. Use the [create shop](#tag/shops/operation/create_shop_api_v1_shops_post) endpoint to create a `shop`. The `ext_shop_id` must be unique within each Pio organization and should be set to something that your integration can use to uniquely idenfity the shop. This `ext_shop_id` will be included in webhook requests to identify the intended target shop.

## Webhook Events and Payload

- `inventory_log.create`: Sent when there is a new entry in the product inventory log. [Example here](#tag/hooks/operation/inventory_log_create_example_api_v1__webhook_documentation_inventory_log_create_post).
- `inventory_levels.update`: Sent when there is update to product stock count in Pio.  [Example here](#tag/hooks/operation/inventory_levels_update_example_api_v1__webhook_documentation_inventory_levels_update_post).
- `fulfillments.create`: Sent when a fulfillment has been created for an order. [Example here](#tag/hooks/operation/fulfillments_create_example_api_v1__webhook_documentation_fulfillments_create_post).
- `fulfillments.update`: Sent when a fulfillment has been updated. [Example here](#tag/hooks/operation/fulfillments_update_example_api_v1__webhook_documentation_fulfillments_update_post).

# Purchase Order Integrations

Purchase Order integrations are responsible for providing Pio with purchase order data. Purchase orders define expected incoming stock. When storing events are matched to a purchase order, Pio will send the integration an update to tell it those specific products have been received.

Purchase Order integrations currently need a `shop` for it's endpoints and webhooks (See the [Shop Integration](#section/ShopPlatformIntegrations) details for how to create a `shop`).

## Webhook Events and Payload

- `purchase_orders.update`: Sent when there is an update to a purchase order. Typically this will be when products are matched to a purchase order during storing. This will inform that some of the items in the purchase order have been received. [Example here](#tag/hooks/operation/purchase_order_update_example_api_v1__webhook_documentation_purchase_orders_update_post).
- `purchase_orders.sync`: received when the user requests a purchase order sync. Useful if you have no automatic mechanism to sync purchase orders with pio but would like the user to be able to fetch changes when they know some are missing from pio. [Example here](#tag/hooks/operation/purchase_order_sync_example_api_v1__webhook_documentation_purchase_orders_sync_post).

# Shipping Integrations

Shipping integrations are responsible for providing possible shipping rates and shipment order, and handling shipment dispatch requests.

## Order Channels

For shipping integrations, the root entity is the [Order Channel](#tag/order_channels).

An order channel defines the relationship between the integration and a webshop or ERP-system.

When creating an order channel a `dispatch_url` must be provided, which is a URL that Pio will `POST` shipment dispatch requests to for that order channel. If there is the possibility you could connect the same order channel to multiple pio organization's, it is important that the `dispatch_url` contains something that you can use to identify the `access_token` you're using to create the order channel for each pairing. If the `dispatch_url` is not unique it will not be possible for you to know which `access_token` to use in the [shipment dispatch flow](#section/Shipping-Integrations/Shipment-Dispatch).

## Shipping Rates

[Shipping rates](#tag/shipping_rates) are provided as a selectable option to the users at the end of the picking process for an order. The selected rate is provided as part of the [Shipment Dispatch request](#section/Shipping-Integrations/Shipment-Dispatch).

## Shipment Orders

[Shipment Orders](#tag/shipment_orders) provides pio with the initial details about the shipment of an order.

Shipment orders are matched to a [fulfillment order](#section/Shop-Platform-Integrations/Orders-and-Fulfillments) using the `ext_order_id`. This can be used to match fulfillment orders created by other integrations (e.g. the pio shopify integration) with shipment orders created by your integration.

The provided shipping rate is used as the default displayed to the user at the end of the picking process for an order.

## Shipment Dispatch

When an order matched to a shipment order from your integration is picked, Pio will send a shipment dispatch request to your integration.

The request is sent to the `dispatch_url` specified when the order channel was created.

See the [Shipment Dispatch request example](#tag/hooks/operation/shipment_dispatch_request_example_openapi_v1__webhook_documentation_shipment_dispatch_post) for details about the request.

The request uses the [webhook (v2)](#section/Webhooks/Version-2-webhooks) structure. i.e. it contains a signature for verification, expects a `2XX` response to indicate it was received successfully, and is expected that the dispatch is processed outside of the http request context. As with webhooks it is also possible that the request may be sent multiple times. Because of this, it is important that you pay attention to the `shipment_id` in the payload, and avoid reprocessing the same request multiple times.

Once the shipment dispatch has been processed, Pio expects a `POST` request sent to the [dispatch response endpoint](#tag/shipments/operation/dispatch_response_openapi_v1_shipments_dispatch_post) with the results of the shipment dispatch.

The dispatch response payload must include the `success` field (either `true` or `false`). If there was a problem with dispatching the shipment, the `success` field should be set to `false` and an `error` field must be included. The `error` message should be something human readable as it will be shown to the users. If the shipment was dispatched successfully, `success` should be `true`, and the `label` field should be provided as a base64 encoded pdf of the shipping label.

If an `error` was returned, another dispatch request may be made for the same order (e.g. the user may change the selected shipping rate and try again), but this will have a different `shipment_id` to distinguish it from previous attempts.

post.description:
Receives updates for transfers to external locations.
When receiving this webhook, the `quantity_delta` should be used to adjust the stock levels for the given external location. The stock levels of pio do not get changed by this, rather an `inventory_logs.create` event will be sent if the external transfer removes stock from pio, and that should be used to adjust the stock levels of pio.

Generated by combining the pio_event_type, pio_delivery_id, pio_timestamp, pio_shop_id, pio_ext_shop_id and raw payload data joined together with a `:` (colon) as a separator. Hashed using hmac_sha256 and base64 encoded. See the [Verification section](#section/Rest-hooks/Verification) at the start of the docs for example code for how to verify the signature

CreateShipmentOrderPayload.title: CreateShipmentOrderPayload
CreateShipmentOrderPayload.description:
Create a shipment order.

This shipment order will be used to create shipments for the associated order.
It is not necessary that the order is created by the same integration. orders
and shipment orders will be matched using the ext_order_id value across integrations.

e.g. if your integration provides shipping support to a shopify store, and the
shopify integration is responsible for handling the orders, your shipping integration
should just use the same shopify order id in the `ext_order_id` field and pio
will match that with the orders provided by the shopify integration.

For specifying the associated order channel and shipping rate, either the external id or the pio id can be used. At least one of these for both the order channel and shipping rate must be present. Both the order channel and shipping rate must exist on pio already for them to be accepted.

`destination` can be `null` assuming the integration is keeping track of it itself. Pio does not need this information.
